greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Quotient n/phi(n) for n in A007694.
comment: Here phi(n) denotes Euler's totient function A000010.

As n increases, the proportion of 3's seems to approach 100 percent (it is 40 percent for the first 10 results; 82 percent for 100 results; 87.5 percent for 200 results while up to 200 million, for the first 235 results, is 88.51 percent). - _Zoltan Galantai_, Jul 28 2019
According to [Ecker and Beslin], the quotients n/phi(n) when phi(n) divides n can take only 3 distinct values:

The previous comment follows because between 2^k and 2^(k+1) there are two consecutive integers for which n/phi(n) = 2, and there are floor(k*(log(2)/log(3)) integers of the form 2^b*3^c (b and c>=1) for which n/phi(n) = 3. (End)
reference: Sárközy A. and Suranyi J., Number Theory Problem Book (in Hungarian), Tankonyvkiado, Budapest, 1972.
link: Jinyuan Wang, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Michael W. Eckert and Scott J. Beslin, Find all positive integers n such that phi(n) divides n, AMM, Vol. 93, No 8, Oct. 86, 656-657, E 3037.
formula: n/phi(n) is an integer iff n = 1 or n = 2^w*3^u for w = 1, 2, ... and u = 0, 1, 2, ...
example: For powers of 2 the quotient is 2.
mathematica: Select[#/EulerPhi@ # & /@ Range[10^6], IntegerQ] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jul 02 2016 *)
program: (MAGMA) v:=[m:m in [1..150000]|m mod EulerPhi(m) eq 0];[v[k]/EulerPhi(v[k]):k in [1..#v]]; // _Marius A. Burtea_, Jul 28 2019
results.author: _Labos Elemer_
